title: MoSEs: Uncertainty-Aware AI-Generated Text Detection via Mixture of Stylistics Experts with Conditional Thresholds
venue: Proceedings of the 2025 Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
abstract: The rapid advancement of large language models has intensified public concerns about the potential misuse. Therefore, it is important to build trustworthy AI-generated text detection systems. Existing methods neglect stylistic modeling and mostly rely on static thresholds, which greatly limits the detection performance. In this paper, we propose the Mixture of Stylistic Experts (MoSEs) framework that enables stylistics-aware uncertainty quantification through conditional threshold estimation. MoSEs contain three core components, namely, the Stylistics Reference Repository (SRR), the Stylistics-Aware Router (SAR), and the Conditional Threshold Estimator (CTE). For input text, SRR can activate the appropriate reference data in SRR and provide them to CTE. Subsequently, CTE jointly models the linguistic statistical properties and semantic features to dynamically determine the optimal threshold. With a discrimination score, MoSEs yields prediction labels with the corresponding confidence level. Our framework achieves an average improvement 11.34% in detection performance compared to baselines. More inspiringly, MoSEs shows a more evident improvement 39.15% in the low-resource case. Our code is available at https://github.com/creator-xi/MoSEs.
abstract_summary_gcp:
The increasing concern over AI misuse necessitates robust detection of AI-generated text, a task where existing methods fall short due to their neglect of stylistic modeling and reliance on static thresholds. To address this, the paper introduces **MoSEs (Mixture of Stylistic Experts)**, a novel framework that enables stylistics-aware uncertainty quantification through conditional threshold estimation.

MoSEs comprises three core components: a **Stylistics Reference Repository (SRR)**, a **Stylistics-Aware Router (SAR)**, and a **Conditional Threshold Estimator (CTE)**. For any input text, the SRR activates relevant reference data which the CTE then uses to dynamically determine an optimal threshold by jointly modeling linguistic statistical properties and semantic features. This allows MoSEs to provide prediction labels with corresponding confidence levels.

The framework significantly improves detection performance, achieving an average 11.34% improvement over baselines, and a more substantial 39.15% improvement in low-resource scenarios. The code for MoSEs is publicly available.

title: Survey of Abstract Meaning Representation: Then, Now, Future
abstract: This paper presents a survey of Abstract Meaning Representation (AMR), a semantic representation framework that captures the meaning of sentences through a graph-based structure. AMR represents sentences as rooted, directed acyclic graphs, where nodes correspond to concepts and edges denote relationships, effectively encoding the meaning of complex sentences. This survey investigates AMR and its extensions, focusing on AMR capabilities. It then explores the parsing (text-to-AMR) and generation (AMR-to-text) tasks by showing traditional, current, and possible futures approaches. It also reviews various applications of AMR including text generation, text classification, and information extraction and information seeking. By analyzing recent developments and challenges in the field, this survey provides insights into future directions for research and the potential impact of AMR on enhancing machine understanding of human language.
abstract_summary_gcp: This paper surveys Abstract Meaning Representation (AMR), a graph-based semantic framework that captures sentence meaning using rooted, directed acyclic graphs where nodes represent concepts and edges denote relationships. The survey explores AMR's capabilities and extensions, examines traditional, current, and future approaches to AMR parsing (text-to-AMR) and generation (AMR-to-text), and reviews its applications in areas like text generation, classification, and information extraction. By analyzing recent developments and challenges, the paper offers insights into future research directions and AMR's potential to enhance machine understanding of human language.

title: Systematizing LLM Persona Design: A Four-Quadrant Technical Taxonomy for AI Companion Applications
abstract: The design and application of LLM-based personas in AI companionship is a rapidly expanding but fragmented field, spanning from virtual emotional compan- ions and game NPCs to embodied functional robots. This diversity in objectives, modality, and technical stacks creates an urgent need for a unified framework. To address this gap, this paper systematizes the field by proposing a Four-Quadrant Technical Taxonomy for AI companion applications. The framework is structured along two critical axes: Virtual vs. Embodied and Emotional Companionship vs. Functional Augmentation. Quadrant I (Virtual Companionship) explores virtual idols, romantic companions, and story characters, introducing a four-layer technical framework to analyze their challenges in maintaining long-term emotional consistency. Quadrant II (Functional Virtual Assistants) analyzes AI applica- tions in work, gaming, and mental health, highlighting the shift from"feeling"to"thinking and acting"and pinpointing key technologies like enterprise RAG and on-device inference. Quadrants III&IV (Embodied Intelligence) shift from the virtual to the physical world, analyzing home robots and vertical-domain assistants, revealing core challenges in symbol grounding, data privacy, and ethical liability. This taxonomy provides not only a systematic map for researchers and developers to navigate the complex persona design space but also a basis for policymakers to identify and address the unique risks inherent in different application scenarios.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper introduces a **Four-Quadrant Technical Taxonomy** to systematize the rapidly expanding but fragmented field of LLM-based AI personas and companionship.

The framework is structured along two critical axes: **Virtual vs. Embodied** and **Emotional Companionship vs. Functional Augmentation**.

1.  **Quadrant I (Virtual Companionship):** Focuses on virtual idols, romantic companions, and story characters, highlighting the challenge of maintaining long-term emotional consistency and proposing a four-layer technical framework.
2.  **Quadrant II (Functional Virtual Assistants):** Addresses AI applications in work, gaming, and mental health, emphasizing the shift from "feeling" to "thinking and acting" with key technologies like enterprise RAG and on-device inference.
3.  **Quadrants III & IV (Embodied Intelligence):** Explores physical-world applications like home robots and vertical-domain assistants, identifying core challenges in symbol grounding, data privacy, and ethical liability.

This taxonomy aims to provide a unified map for researchers and developers, while also serving as a basis for policymakers to understand and mitigate risks across diverse AI companion scenarios.

title: Aligning Large Language Models with Procedural Rules: An Autoregressive State-Tracking Prompting for In-Game Trading
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) enable dynamic game interactions but fail to follow essential procedural flows in rule-governed trading systems, eroding player trust. This work resolves the core tension between the creative flexibility of LLMs and the procedural demands of in-game trading (browse-offer-review-confirm). To this end, Autoregressive State-Tracking Prompting (ASTP) is introduced, a methodology centered on a strategically orchestrated prompt that compels an LLM to make its state-tracking process explicit and verifiable. Instead of relying on implicit contextual understanding, ASTP tasks the LLM with identifying and reporting a predefined state label from the previous turn. To ensure transactional integrity, this is complemented by a state-specific placeholder post-processing method for accurate price calculations. Evaluation across 300 trading dialogues demonstrates>99% state compliance and 99.3% calculation precision. Notably, ASTP with placeholder post-processing on smaller models (Gemini-2.5-Flash) matches larger models'(Gemini-2.5-Pro) performance while reducing response time from 21.2s to 2.4s, establishing a practical foundation that satisfies both real-time requirements and resource constraints of commercial games.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This work addresses the challenge of integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) into rule-governed game trading systems. While LLMs offer dynamic interactions, they often fail to follow essential procedural flows (like browse-offer-review-confirm), undermining player trust.

The proposed solution is **Autoregressive State-Tracking Prompting (ASTP)**. This methodology involves a strategically designed prompt that compels the LLM to explicitly track and report a predefined state label from the previous turn, making its internal state understanding verifiable. To ensure transactional integrity, ASTP is complemented by a **state-specific placeholder post-processing method** for accurate price calculations.

Evaluations across 300 trading dialogues demonstrated impressive results: ASTP achieved over 99% state compliance and 99.3% calculation precision. Crucially, applying ASTP with placeholder post-processing enabled smaller models (Gemini-2.5-Flash) to match the performance of larger models (Gemini-2.5-Pro) while drastically reducing response times from 21.2 seconds to 2.4 seconds. This establishes a practical and efficient foundation for implementing LLM-powered trading systems in commercial games, satisfying both real-time requirements and resource constraints.

title: Survey of Large Language Models in Extended Reality: Technical Paradigms and Application Frontiers
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in natural language understanding and generation, and their integration with Extended Reality (XR) is poised to transform how users interact with immersive environments. This survey provides a comprehensive review of recent developments at the intersection of LLMs and XR, offering a structured organization of research along both technical and application dimensions. We propose a taxonomy of LLM-enhanced XR systems centered on key technical paradigms -- such as interactive agent control, XR development toolkits, and generative scene synthesis -- and discuss how these paradigms enable novel capabilities in XR. In parallel, we examine how LLM-driven techniques support practical XR applications across diverse domains, including immersive education, clinical healthcare, and industrial manufacturing. By connecting these technical paradigms with application frontiers, our survey highlights current trends, delineates design considerations, and identifies open challenges in building LLM-augmented XR systems. This work provides insights that can guide researchers and practitioners in advancing the state of the art in intelligent XR experiences.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This survey comprehensively reviews the integration of Large Language Models (LLMs) with Extended Reality (XR), highlighting how LLMs' natural language capabilities are poised to transform user interaction in immersive environments. It offers a structured overview of recent developments, categorized by both technical approaches and application domains.

The survey proposes a taxonomy of LLM-enhanced XR systems based on technical paradigms such as interactive agent control, XR development toolkits, and generative scene synthesis, explaining how these enable novel XR functionalities. Concurrently, it explores practical LLM-driven applications across diverse fields including immersive education, clinical healthcare, and industrial manufacturing.

By connecting these technical advancements with real-world applications, the work delineates current trends, design considerations, and open challenges. Its ultimate goal is to provide insights that guide researchers and practitioners in developing more intelligent and interactive XR experiences.

title: State-Inference-Based Prompting for Natural Language Trading with Game NPCs
abstract: Large Language Models enable dynamic game interactions but struggle with rule-governed trading systems. Current implementations suffer from rule violations, such as item hallucinations and calculation errors, that erode player trust. Here, State-Inference-Based Prompting (SIBP) enables reliable trading through autonomous dialogue state inference and context-specific rule adherence. The approach decomposes trading into six states within a unified prompt framework, implementing context-aware item referencing and placeholder-based price calculations. Evaluation across 100 trading dialogues demonstrates>97% state compliance,>95% referencing accuracy, and 99.7% calculation precision. SIBP maintains computational efficiency while outperforming baseline approaches, establishing a practical foundation for trustworthy NPC interactions in commercial games.
abstract_summary_gcp:
Large Language Models (LLMs) can create dynamic game interactions but fail when it comes to rule-governed trading systems due to errors like item "hallucinations" and incorrect calculations, which erode player trust.

To solve this, State-Inference-Based Prompting (SIBP) is proposed. SIBP enables reliable trading by autonomously inferring dialogue states and enforcing rules specific to the context. It breaks down trading into six distinct states within a single prompt framework, using context-aware item referencing and placeholder-based price calculations.

Evaluations demonstrate SIBP's effectiveness: over 97% state compliance, over 95% referencing accuracy, and 99.7% calculation precision across 100 trading dialogues. SIBP is also computationally efficient and outperforms baseline approaches, providing a practical way to create trustworthy NPC interactions in commercial games.

title: SAFT: Structure-Aware Fine-Tuning of LLMs for AMR-to-Text Generation
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly applied to tasks involving structured inputs such as graphs. Abstract Meaning Representations (AMRs), which encode rich semantics as directed graphs, offer a rigorous testbed for evaluating LLMs on text generation from such structures. Yet, current methods often arbitrarily linearize AMRs, discarding key structural cues, or rely on architectures incompatible with standard LLMs. We introduce SAFT, a structure-aware fine-tuning approach that injects graph topology into pretrained LLMs without architectural changes. We compute direction-sensitive positional encodings from the magnetic Laplacian of transformed AMRs and project them into the embedding space of the LLM. While possibly applicable to any graph-structured inputs, we focus on AMR-to-text generation as a representative and challenging benchmark. SAFT sets a new state-of-the-art on AMR 3.0 with a 3.5 BLEU improvement over baselines. Gains scale with graph complexity, highlighting the value of structure-aware representations in enhancing LLM performance. SAFT offers a general and effective pathway for bridging structured data and language models.
abstract_summary_gcp:
The paper introduces **SAFT (Structure-Aware Fine-Tuning)**, a novel approach to enhance Large Language Models (LLMs) for tasks involving structured inputs like Abstract Meaning Representations (AMRs).

Current methods for processing AMRs for text generation often lose crucial structural information by linearizing the graphs or require incompatible architectural changes. SAFT addresses this by injecting the graph's topology directly into pre-trained LLMs *without* modifying their architecture. It achieves this by computing **direction-sensitive positional encodings** from the magnetic Laplacian of transformed AMRs and projecting these into the LLM's embedding space.

Tested on the challenging AMR-to-text generation task, SAFT sets a new state-of-the-art on AMR 3.0, achieving a **3.5 BLEU improvement** over existing baselines. The benefits of SAFT are more pronounced with increasing graph complexity, underscoring the value of structure-aware representations. This method offers a general and effective way to bridge structured data with language models.

LiTformer: Efficient Signal Integrity Analysis for High-Speed Link Transmitters Using Non-Autoregressive Transformer
venue: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: High-speed serial links are essential for low-latency, high-bandwidth communication in data-intensive systems. Signal integrity (SI) of transmitters (TXs) directly impacts transmission quality of the links, while TXs’ delay also introduces timing mismatches that degrade link integrity. In this article, we propose LiTformer, a Transformer-based model for efficient SI analysis of high-speed link TXs, featuring a nonsequential encoder and a multihead Transformer decoder to incorporate link parameters and capture long-range dependencies. By adopting a non-autoregressive approach, it enables parallel sequence prediction. We also introduce an ANN-based delay model for fast TX delay estimation. Considering link factors, including crosstalk in multiple-link systems, LiTformer enables accurate and fast long-sequence signal prediction at high data rates, achieving efficient SI analysis for TXs. Experimental results show LiTformer achieves <inline-formula> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$437\times $ </tex-math></inline-formula>–<inline-formula> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$996\times $ </tex-math></inline-formula> speedup in eye diagram prediction over SPICE, with mean errors of 0.15%–1.57%. It supports 4-bit signals at Gbps data rates for single-ended and differential TXs, including NRZ and PAM4 formats. The delay model predicts TX delay achieving a speedup of four orders of magnitude with errors of 0.86%–2.69%.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper introduces **LiTformer**, a Transformer-based model for efficient signal integrity (SI) analysis of high-speed link transmitters (TXs). High-speed links require excellent SI and minimal TX delay, which often degrade transmission quality.

LiTformer addresses this by employing a nonsequential encoder to integrate link parameters (including crosstalk) and a multihead Transformer decoder to capture long-range signal dependencies. Its non-autoregressive nature enables parallel sequence prediction, facilitating fast analysis. An accompanying ANN-based delay model is also proposed for rapid TX delay estimation.

Experimental results demonstrate significant performance:
*   LiTformer achieves a **437x–996x speedup** in eye diagram prediction compared to SPICE, with mean errors ranging from 0.15%–1.57%.
*   It supports 4-bit NRZ and PAM4 signals at Gbps data rates for both single-ended and differential TXs.
*   The delay model offers a **four orders of magnitude speedup** in TX delay prediction, with errors between 0.86%–2.69%.

Overall, LiTformer provides an accurate and fast solution for long-sequence signal prediction and SI analysis in high-speed TXs.

title: InDenT: An Energy-Efficient 2.5D System With Heterogeneous Reconfigurable Interconnect for Dense Foundational Models
venue: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Dense transformer algorithms have shown supreme accuracy while executing machine intelligence tasks by introducing dense connections between various computing blocks. However, the introduction of dense connections increases computation and communication volume which increases latency and energy consumption. Therefore, we propose a 2.5D system with heterogeneous reconfigurable interconnect for energy-efficient execution of dense transformer algorithms. Our proposed 2.5D system includes in-memory computing (IMC) as well as CMOS components to execute different types of computations involved in a dense transformer. Our proposed heterogeneous reconfigurable interconnect comprises on-package wired as well as wireless links to reduce communication latency. The interconnect is reconfigurable since at runtime it is decided which wireless links are to be utilized. Extensive experimental evaluations with different dense transformers show an improvement of up to 39.32% in communication latency with respect to state-of-the-art 2.5D systems.
abstract_summary_gcp:
Dense transformer algorithms achieve high accuracy but at the cost of increased computation, communication, latency, and energy consumption due to their dense connections. To address this, the paper proposes a **2.5D system with a heterogeneous reconfigurable interconnect** for energy-efficient execution.

This system integrates **in-memory computing (IMC) and CMOS components** for different types of computations. Its novel interconnect combines **on-package wired and reconfigurable wireless links**, where wireless links are dynamically utilized at runtime to reduce communication latency. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that this approach improves communication latency by up to 39.32% compared to existing 2.5D systems.

title: Production Disentanglement and Exogenous Analysis Transformer for Petroleum Production Prediction
abstract: Petroleum production prediction is a crucial task in reservoir monitoring and management, providing an indispensable basis for development scheme optimization. Most existing production prediction methods learn a joint representation for production dynamics using deep neural networks. However, these methods ignore the special temporal patterns of production dynamics and do not quantitatively analyze the impact of exogenous engineering measures on production. This may lead to insufficient generalization and guidance of the model in practical applications. To address these limitations, we propose a novel production analysis transformer for petroleum production prediction. Specifically, we leverage position enhancement and long-term interaction to explicitly capture the distinctive temporal patterns of production dynamics including local fluctuation and trend features. Furthermore, we establish covariate-level attention to evaluate the dynamic contribution of exogenous engineering measures to production. In this process, we design an adaptive aggregate mechanism that enables multihead attention to generate a single attention response, thereby improving the legibility of attention maps in engineering applications while maintaining the diversity of feature learning. With this task-specific design, our model learns disentangled production patterns and quantified exogenous influences, thereby enabling accurate and insightful production prediction. Comprehensive experiments on two real-world datasets demonstrate the advantages of our method in production prediction and its significance in engineering guidance.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper addresses limitations in current deep learning methods for petroleum production prediction, which often neglect special temporal patterns and fail to quantitatively analyze the impact of exogenous engineering measures.

The authors propose a novel **production analysis transformer** designed to overcome these issues. Key features of their approach include:
1.  **Temporal Pattern Capture:** It leverages position enhancement and long-term interaction to explicitly model distinctive temporal dynamics, such as local fluctuations and overall trends.
2.  **Exogenous Influence Quantification:** It introduces covariate-level attention to dynamically evaluate the contribution of external engineering measures to production.
3.  **Enhanced Interpretability:** An adaptive aggregate mechanism for multihead attention generates a single, legible attention response, improving interpretability for engineers while preserving feature learning diversity.

This task-specific design enables the model to learn disentangled production patterns and quantify exogenous influences, leading to accurate and insightful predictions. Experiments on two real-world datasets demonstrate the method's advantages in prediction and its significance for engineering guidance.

title: Nonconvex Low-Tubal-Rank Tensor Completion With Temporal Regularization for Spatiotemporal Traffic Data Recovery
venue: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: Spatiotemporal traffic data collected by sensor networks is paramount for intelligent transportation systems, but it often suffers from significant missing values, making accurate recovery a critical challenge. This paper introduces a nonconvex low-tubal-rank tensor completion model with temporal regularization (NLTC-TR) to fill in missing data based on the underlying physical properties of spatiotemporal traffic data, including similarity and periodicity. Our model can capture both the global correlations across different modes of traffic data and the local temporal variations. Specifically, we first present a unified nonconvex model to capture tubal rank along different dimensions while considering the specificity in each mode. The nonconvexity achieved by synergizing logarithm and Schatten-p norm serves as a tight rank approximation. In doing so, the low-rank property of traffic data can be better modeled in the transformed domains. Furthermore, by introducing a temporal regularization, we can make better use of the local variation between adjacent moments. To solve this problem, we propose an efficient iterative algorithm based on the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM), where each step can be solved in closed form. Numerical experiments on two real-world traffic datasets with varying missing patterns show that our method outperforms existing algorithms, demonstrating its effectiveness in accurately recovering missing traffic data.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper addresses the critical challenge of recovering significant missing values in spatiotemporal traffic data, which is essential for intelligent transportation systems.

The authors propose a novel method called **Nonconvex Low-Tubal-rank Tensor Completion model with Temporal Regularization (NLTC-TR)**. This model is designed to leverage the underlying physical properties of traffic data, such as similarity and periodicity, to accurately fill in missing information.

Key features of NLTC-TR include:
*   **Capturing Global and Local Correlations:** It simultaneously accounts for global correlations across different modes of traffic data and local temporal variations.
*   **Unified Nonconvex Model:** It employs a unified nonconvex model that captures tubal rank along various dimensions, considering the specificity of each mode.
*   **Tight Rank Approximation:** Nonconvexity is achieved through a synergy of logarithm and Schatten-p norms, providing a tighter approximation of rank that better models the low-rank property of traffic data in transformed domains.
*   **Temporal Regularization:** An explicit temporal regularization term is introduced to effectively utilize local variations between adjacent time steps.

To solve this complex problem, the paper proposes an efficient iterative algorithm based on the **Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM)**, where each step can be solved in closed form.

Numerical experiments conducted on two real-world traffic datasets with varying missing patterns demonstrate that NLTC-TR significantly outperforms existing algorithms, proving its effectiveness in accurately and robustly recovering missing spatiotemporal traffic data.

title: Efficient Transformer Inference Through Hybrid Dynamic Pruning
abstract: In the world of deep learning, transformer models have become very significant, leading to improvements in many areas, from understanding language to recognizing images, covering a wide range of applications. Despite their success, the deployment of these models in real-time applications, particularly on edge devices, poses significant challenges due to their computational intensity and memory demands. To overcome these challenges, we introduce a novel hybrid dynamic pruning (HDP) technique, an efficient algorithm-architecture codesign approach that accelerates transformers using head sparsity, block sparsity, and approximation to reduce computations in attention and reduce memory access. With the observation of the huge redundancy in attention scores and attention heads, we propose a novel integer-based block pruning to prune unimportant blocks in the attention matrix at run time. We also propose integer-based head pruning to detect and prune unimportant heads at an early stage at run time. Also, we propose an approximation method that reduces attention computations. To efficiently support these methods with lower latency, we propose the HDP accelerator (HDPA) as a coprocessor architecture, synthesized in two configurations—HDPA-edge and HDPA-server—to meet the needs of mobile and server platforms. Extensive experiments with different transformer models and benchmarks demonstrate that HDPA-server achieves <inline-formula> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$481\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> and <inline-formula> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$381\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> speedup in attention layer computation over Intel i7-1185G7 CPU and NVIDIA T4 GPU, respectively. Compared to other state-of-the-art (SOTA) accelerators, HDPA achieves <inline-formula> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.26\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> to <inline-formula> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.08\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> higher throughput, <inline-formula> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.3\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> to <inline-formula> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$18\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> greater MAC efficiency, and <inline-formula> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.1\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> to <inline-formula> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$5.1\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> improved energy efficiency, when normalized to the same computational load.
abstract_summary_gcp:
Transformer models, while highly successful across various deep learning applications, face significant challenges for real-time and edge deployment due to their intensive computational and memory demands. To overcome this, the paper introduces a novel **hybrid dynamic pruning (HDP)** technique, an efficient algorithm-architecture codesign approach.

HDP accelerates transformers by leveraging head sparsity, block sparsity, and approximation to reduce computations in the attention mechanism and lower memory access. Specifically, it proposes novel integer-based block pruning to dynamically remove unimportant blocks in the attention matrix at runtime, and integer-based head pruning to detect and prune uncritical attention heads early at runtime. An approximation method further reduces attention computations.

To efficiently support these techniques, the paper designs the **HDP accelerator (HDPA)** as a coprocessor architecture, synthesized in two configurations: HDPA-edge for mobile platforms and HDPA-server for server environments.

Extensive experiments demonstrate that HDPA-server achieves substantial speedups in the attention layer computation, including 481x over an Intel i7-1185G7 CPU and 381x over an NVIDIA T4 GPU. Compared to other state-of-the-art accelerators, and normalized to the same computational load, HDPA delivers 1.26x to 2.08x higher throughput, 1.3x to 18x greater MAC efficiency, and 1.1x to 5.1x improved energy efficiency.

title: Generalization-Enhanced Feature-Wise and Correlation Attentions for Cross-Database Facial Expression Recognition
venue: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: Cross-database facial expression recognition (CDFER) has attracted increasing attention when evaluating the systems' generalization performance. Although the attention mechanism can capture the feature-wise importance or feature-correlation of expression sensitive regions, the attention-based network suffers from the overfitting to the source database, due to possible over-dependence on most salient features, without exploring feature characteristics during removal of feature redundancy. To address this issue, this paper introduces a multi-kernel competitive convolution in feature-wise attention to obtain more salient regions and let each kernel compete with others to enhance the expressive ability of features, by reducing attention overfitting to the source domain. For feature-correlation attention, we resort to a Monte Carlo-based dropout to not only reduce the over-learning of the feature relationship, but also model the dropout probability distribution more specifically by taking the characteristics of feature maps into account. Experimental results show that our algorithm achieves much better generalization performances than the state of the arts (SOTAs) on six publicly available datasets, in the scenarios of single source domain, multiple source domains and domain adaption.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper addresses the challenge of overfitting to source databases in cross-database facial expression recognition (CDFER) models that utilize attention mechanisms. Existing attention-based networks tend to over-rely on highly salient features and don't adequately manage feature redundancy, hindering generalization.

To overcome this, the authors propose a novel approach with two main contributions:

1.  **Multi-kernel competitive convolution for feature-wise attention:** This technique helps identify a wider range of salient regions and encourages competition among kernels to boost feature expressiveness, thereby reducing attention overfitting to the source domain.
2.  **Monte Carlo-based dropout for feature-correlation attention:** This method is used to mitigate the over-learning of feature relationships. It achieves this by modeling dropout probability distributions specifically based on the characteristics of the feature maps, which aids in handling feature redundancy.

Experimental results show that their algorithm significantly improves generalization performance compared to state-of-the-art methods across six public datasets, in single source, multiple source, and domain adaptation scenarios.

SSpMM: Efficiently Scalable SpMM Kernels Across Multiple Generations of Tensor Cores
venue: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: Sparse-Dense Matrix-Matrix Multiplication (SpMM) has emerged as a foundational primitive in HPC and AI. Recent advancements have aimed to accelerate SpMM by harnessing the powerful Tensor Cores found in modern GPUs. However, despite these efforts, existing methods frequently encounter performance degradation when ported across different Tensor Core architectures. Recognizing that scalable SpMM across multiple generations of Tensor Cores relies on the effective use of general-purpose instructions, we have meticulously developed a SpMM library named SSpMM. However, a significant conflict exists between granularity and performance in current Tensor Core instructions. To resolve this, we introduce the innovative Transpose Mapping Scheme, which elegantly implements fine-grained kernels using coarse-grained instructions. Additionally, we propose the Register Shuffle Method to further enhance performance. Finally, we introduce Sparse Vector Compression, a technique that ensures our kernels are scalable with both structured and unstructured sparsity. Our experimental results, conducted on four generations of Tensor Core GPUs using over 3,000 sparse matrices from well-established matrix collections, demonstrate that SSpMM achieves an average speedup of 2.04 ×, 2.81 ×, 2.07 ×, and 1.87 ×, respectively, over the state-of-the-art SpMM solution. Furthermore, we have integrated SSpMM into PyTorch, achieving a 1.81 × speedup in end-to-end Transformer inference compared to cuDNN.
abstract_summary_gcp:
Sparse-Dense Matrix-Matrix Multiplication (SpMM) is a fundamental operation in HPC and AI, with recent efforts focusing on accelerating it using GPU Tensor Cores. However, existing methods often suffer from performance degradation and lack portability across different Tensor Core architectures.

To address this, the authors developed **SSpMM**, a novel SpMM library designed for scalability across multiple Tensor Core generations by effectively utilizing general-purpose instructions. SSpMM overcomes the inherent conflict between granularity and performance in current Tensor Core instructions through three key innovations:

1.  **Transpose Mapping Scheme:** This technique elegantly implements fine-grained kernels using coarse-grained Tensor Core instructions.
2.  **Register Shuffle Method:** Further enhances performance.
3.  **Sparse Vector Compression:** Ensures scalability with both structured and unstructured sparsity.

Evaluated on four generations of Tensor Core GPUs with over 3,000 sparse matrices, SSpMM consistently achieved significant speedups over the state-of-the-art SpMM solution, ranging from an average of 1.87x to 2.81x. Moreover, its integration into PyTorch demonstrated a 1.81x speedup in end-to-end Transformer inference compared to cuDNN.

Learning to Explore Efficiently: Heterogeneous Topological Graphs and Lightweight Global Reasoning for Robotic Exploration
abstract: Autonomous exploration in large-scale, unknown environments remains a significant challenge in mobile robotics. In this letter, we propose a scalable exploration framework that integrates heterogeneous topological representations, lightweight global-local graph reasoning, and reinforcement learning. Our framework is computationally efficient, comprehensively considers global spatial context, and generalizes effectively across diverse environmental scenarios. We introduce a compact topological abstraction to encode crucial spatial and semantic information, substantially reducing map complexity. A novel hybrid inference module, combining linear global attention with local graph convolutions, effectively integrates long-range exploration with comprehensive local coverage. We further design a minimalist reward function paired with a curriculum learning to ensure stable training and enhanced generalization. A viewpoint-based action masking mechanism further refines the action space, accelerating learning convergence. Extensive simulations demonstrate our method consistently surpasses state-of-the-art baselines, achieving up to 14.5% shorter exploration time and 18.8% reduced path length while maintaining low computational overhead. Real-world experiments further validate the practical effectiveness of our approach for robotic exploration tasks.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper introduces a scalable framework for autonomous exploration in large, unknown robotic environments. The framework integrates heterogeneous topological representations, lightweight global-local graph reasoning, and reinforcement learning to achieve computational efficiency, comprehensive global context, and effective generalization.

Key components include:
1.  A **compact topological abstraction** that encodes crucial spatial and semantic information to significantly reduce map complexity.
2.  A **novel hybrid inference module** that combines linear global attention with local graph convolutions, enabling both long-range exploration and comprehensive local coverage.
3.  A **minimalist reward function** paired with curriculum learning to ensure stable training and enhanced generalization for the reinforcement learning agent.
4.  A **viewpoint-based action masking mechanism** to refine the action space and accelerate learning convergence.

Extensive simulations show the method outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving up to 14.5% shorter exploration times and 18.8% reduced path lengths with low computational overhead. Real-world experiments further validate its practical effectiveness.

title: STAF-Navi: Vision-Based Spatio-Temporal Attention Fusion Navigation Framework
abstract: In cluttered, unknown, and partially observable environments, Uncrewed Aerial Vehicle (UAV) navigation encounters formidable challenges. To address these challenges, we propose an innovative spatio-temporal attention fusion navigation framework called STAF-Navi. The framework integrates spatio-temporal attention mechanisms to model sequential dependencies. It captures spatial and temporal correlations from historical observations and actions to improve navigation and obstacle avoidance. STAF-Navi employs deep collision encoding to compress high-dimensional depth images into informative low-dimensional latent states, and a single-site Transformer to model historical sensor inputs and states, enhancing the utility of current observations. By exploiting temporal dependencies, this integration enables early braking and stable hovering. Extensive simulation experiments show that the framework increases the navigation success rate by 10% and improves path efficiency by 7%. Finally, the successful deployment of the proposed strategy in real-world scenarios validates its effectiveness.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper introduces STAF-Navi, an innovative spatio-temporal attention fusion navigation framework designed to overcome the challenges of UAV navigation in cluttered, unknown, and partially observable environments.

STAF-Navi integrates spatio-temporal attention mechanisms to model sequential dependencies, capturing spatial and temporal correlations from historical observations and actions. Key components include deep collision encoding, which compresses high-dimensional depth images into low-dimensional latent states, and a single-site Transformer that leverages historical sensor inputs and states to enhance current observations.

This approach significantly improves navigation and obstacle avoidance by enabling early braking and stable hovering. Simulation experiments demonstrated a 10% increase in navigation success rate and a 7% improvement in path efficiency. The framework's effectiveness was further validated through successful real-world deployment.

title: Generative Diffusion Model-Assisted Efficient Fingerprinting for In-Orchard Localization
abstract: Precise robot localization at the tree level is essential for smart agriculture applications such as precision disease management and targeted nutrient distribution. Existing methods fail to achieve the required accuracy. We propose OrchLoc, a fingerprinting-based localization solution that achieves tree-level precision using a single Long Range (LoRa) gateway. Our approach utilizes channel state information (CSI) across eight channels as a localization fingerprint. To minimize labor-intensive site surveys for fingerprint database construction and maintenance, we develop a CSI generative model (CGM) that learns the relationship between CSI vectors and their corresponding locations. The CGM is fine-tuned using CSI data from static agricultural LoRa sensor nodes, enabling continuous fingerprint database updates. Extensive experiments in two orchards demonstrate that OrchLoc effectively achieves accurate tree-level localization with minimal overhead, improving robot navigation.
abstract_summary_gcp: OrchLoc is a proposed localization solution designed for precise, tree-level robot navigation in smart agriculture, addressing the inadequacy of existing methods. It utilizes a fingerprinting-based approach, leveraging Channel State Information (CSI) across eight channels from a single LoRa gateway. A key innovation is the CSI Generative Model (CGM), which learns the relationship between CSI vectors and locations to automate fingerprint database construction and continuous updates. The CGM is fine-tuned using data from static LoRa sensor nodes, reducing manual effort. Experiments in two orchards confirm that OrchLoc delivers accurate tree-level localization with minimal overhead, thereby enhancing robot navigation capabilities.

title: User Context Generation for Large Language Models From Mobile Sensing Data
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) exhibit remarkable capabilities in natural language understanding and generation. However, the accuracy of the inference depends deeply on the contexts of queries, especially for personal services. Abundant mobile sensing data collected by sensors embedded in smart devices can proactively capture real-time user contexts. However, raw sensing data are low-quality (e.g., existing missing data and data redundancy) and are incapable of providing accurate contexts. In this work, we present ConGen, a user context generation framework for LLMs, aiming at prompting users’ contexts through their implicit mobile sensing information. ConGen integrates two components: refined data completion and multi-granularity context compression. Specifically, the refined data completion couples data-centric feature selection by leveraging the eXplainable AI (XAI) method into the data imputation model to generate fewer but more informative features for efficient and effective context generation. Additionally, we implement multi-granularity context compression, reducing timestep- and context-level data redundancy while further elevating context quality. Experiment results show that ConGen can generate more accurate context, surpassing competitive baselines by 1.3%-8.3% in context inference on all four datasets. Moreover, context compression significantly reduces redundancy to <inline-formula><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1/70\sim 1/40$</tex-math><alternatives><mml:math><mml:mrow><mml:mn>1</mml:mn><mml:mo>/</mml:mo><mml:mn>70</mml:mn><mml:mo>∼</mml:mo><mml:mn>1</mml:mn><mml:mo>/</mml:mo><mml:mn>40</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math><inline-graphic xlink:href="zheng-ieq1-3591561.gif"/></alternatives></inline-formula> of the original data amount, and further improves the context accuracy. Finally, the enhanced performance of LLMs, as demonstrated by both quantitative and qualitative evaluations of prompting ConGen-generated user contexts, underscores the effectiveness of ConGen.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper introduces **ConGen**, a novel user context generation framework designed to provide high-quality contextual information for Large Language Models (LLMs) from implicit mobile sensing data.

The problem ConGen addresses is that while LLMs benefit greatly from accurate contexts for personalized services, raw mobile sensing data is often low-quality (e.g., missing data, redundancy) and thus unreliable for direct use.

ConGen tackles this through two main components:
1.  **Refined Data Completion:** This component integrates data-centric feature selection using eXplainable AI (XAI) with a data imputation model. Its goal is to generate a smaller, more informative set of features, leading to efficient and effective context generation.
2.  **Multi-granularity Context Compression:** This component reduces both timestep- and context-level data redundancy, which not only shrinks the data footprint but also further elevates the quality of the generated contexts.

Experimental results show ConGen significantly improves context inference accuracy by 1.3%-8.3% over baselines across four datasets. The context compression is highly effective, reducing data redundancy to 1/70 to 1/40 of the original amount, while surprisingly *also* enhancing context accuracy. Ultimately, LLMs demonstrate improved performance when prompted with ConGen-generated user contexts, underscoring the framework's effectiveness.

title: CrowdNet: Adaptive Collaborative Inference for Dynamic Mobile Intelligent Service
Traffic-Aware Load Balancing Based on Deep Reinforcement Learning in Cloud-Based Industrial Data Centers
abstract: Modern industrial datacenter networks employ multirooted tree topologies to accommodate a diverse range of cloud applications, which generate heterogeneous traffic with low-latency short flows and high-throughput long flows. Recently, the proposed learning-based load balancing mechanisms are resilient to dynamic network, but they are agnostic to heterogeneous traffic, resulting in large tail delay. In this article, we propose a new deep reinforcement learning (DRL) based load balancing called DRLB, which uses DRL with the distributed distributional deterministic policy gradients algorithm to make (re)routing for long flows, and adopts the weighted cost multipathing mechanism for short flows. Furthermore, this article introduces a traffic feature-based dynamic training cycle mechanism to adaptively adjust the training cycles. The experimental results show DRLB reduces the flow completion time of short flows by up to 58% and improves the throughput of long flows by 38% compared to the state-of-the-art load balancing mechanisms.
abstract_summary_gcp:
Modern datacenter networks, despite using multirooted tree topologies, struggle with heterogeneous traffic (low-latency short flows and high-throughput long flows). Existing learning-based load balancing mechanisms, while resilient, are agnostic to this traffic diversity, leading to large tail delays.

This article introduces **DRLB**, a new deep reinforcement learning (DRL) based load balancing mechanism designed to address this. DRLB intelligently handles heterogeneous traffic by:
1.  Utilizing a DRL algorithm (distributed distributional deterministic policy gradients) for the (re)routing of **long flows**.
2.  Employing a weighted cost multipathing mechanism for **short flows**.

Furthermore, DRLB incorporates a traffic feature-based dynamic training cycle mechanism to adaptively adjust its learning. Experimental results show DRLB significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, reducing short flow completion time by up to 58% and improving long flow throughput by 38%.

title: DSTE-Net: Dual-Scale Spatial-Temporal Excitation Network for Dynamic Gesture Recognition
abstract: Dynamic gesture recognition is a crucial technology for achieving natural human-computer interaction and holds broad application prospects in fields such as virtual reality, smart home, and digital entertainment. However, existing methods often lack a unified mechanism to simultaneously capture subtle local motion features and global semantic context, which are both essential for accurate recognition. To address this limitation, we propose a Dual-scale Spatial-Temporal Excitation (DSTE) module that explicitly integrates temporal and spatial features across both local and global scales, enhancing the network to effectively capture fine-grained motion and long-range dependencies. The plug-and-play DSTE module can be seamlessly incorporated into standard 2D architectures such as ResNet-50, forming a more expressive framework referred to as DSTE-Net, while adding only 1.99 GFLOPs. Extensive experiments on the EgoGesture, IPNHand, and LD-ConGR datasets using only RGB videos as input demonstrate that DSTE-Net achieves superior performance compared with state-of-the-art methods.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper addresses a limitation in dynamic gesture recognition, where current methods struggle to simultaneously capture crucial subtle local motion features and global semantic context. To solve this, the authors propose a **Dual-scale Spatial-Temporal Excitation (DSTE) module**. This module explicitly integrates temporal and spatial features across both local and global scales, enabling the network to effectively capture fine-grained motion and long-range dependencies.

The DSTE module is plug-and-play, allowing seamless integration into standard 2D architectures (like ResNet-50) to form **DSTE-Net**, with a minimal computational overhead of only 1.99 GFLOPs. Experiments on the EgoGesture, IPNHand, and LD-ConGR datasets, using only RGB video input, demonstrate that DSTE-Net achieves superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: UniTrans: A Unified Vertical Federated Knowledge Transfer Framework for Enhancing Edge Healthcare Collaboration
abstract: Cross-hospital collaboration has the potential to mitigate disparities in medical resources across different regions. However, strict privacy regulations prohibit the direct sharing of sensitive patient information between hospitals. Vertical federated learning (VFL) provides a novel privacy-preserving machine learning paradigm designed to maximizes data utility across multiple hospitals. Nevertheless, traditional VFL methods primarily benefit patients with overlapping data, leaving non-overlapping patients without guaranteed improvements in distributed healthcare prediction services. While some existing knowledge transfer techniques attempt to improve prediction performance for non-overlapping patients, they fail to adequately address scenarios where overlapping and non-overlapping patients originate from different domains, resulting in challenges such as feature and label heterogeneity. To address these issues, we propose UniTrans, a unified vertical federated knowledge transfer framework for edge healthcare collaboration. Our framework consists of three key steps. First, we extract the federated representation of overlapping patients by employing an effective vertical federated representation learning method to model multi-party joint features online. Next, each hospital learns a local knowledge transfer module offline, enabling the domain-adaptive transfer of knowledge from the federated representation of overlapping patients to the enriched representation of local non-overlapping patients. Finally, hospitals utilize these enriched local representations to enhance performance across various downstream medical prediction tasks. Extensive experiments on real-world medical datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and scalability of UniTrans in both intra-domain and cross-domain knowledge transfer.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper addresses the challenge of leveraging cross-hospital collaboration to mitigate medical resource disparities while respecting patient privacy. While Vertical Federated Learning (VFL) offers a privacy-preserving solution, its benefits are primarily limited to patients with overlapping data, leaving non-overlapping patients underserved. Existing knowledge transfer techniques fall short when overlapping and non-overlapping patients originate from different domains, leading to issues like feature and label heterogeneity.

To overcome these challenges, the authors propose **UniTrans**, a unified vertical federated knowledge transfer framework for edge healthcare. UniTrans operates in three steps:
1.  It extracts federated representations of overlapping patients through multi-party joint feature modeling.
2.  Each hospital then learns a local, domain-adaptive knowledge transfer module offline to enrich the representations of its non-overlapping patients using knowledge from the federated overlapping representations.
3.  Finally, these enriched local representations are used to enhance various downstream medical prediction tasks.

Extensive experiments confirm UniTrans's effectiveness and scalability for both intra-domain and cross-domain knowledge transfer on real-world medical datasets.

title: A Joint FDIA Detection and Localization Scheme and Experimental Analysis Based on Adversarial Anomaly Transformer for Power Distribution System
abstract: The false data injection attacks (FDIA) pose significant threats to the security of the power distribution systems, underscoring the critical need for efficient FDIA detection and localization schemes. In this article, a joint FDIA detection and localization scheme based on an adversarial anomaly transformer is proposed, and the experimental analysis is performed using a developed cyber-physical power distribution simulation system testbed. To address the prevalent overgeneralization issue in reconstruction-based unsupervised methods, an anomaly attention mechanism is first introduced into the FDIA detection and localization scheme to amplify the distinguishability between normal and attacked data. Subsequently, a generative adversarial network framework is used to capture the distribution of data accurately. In addition, the drift streaming peaks over threshold dynamic threshold method is used to adapt to fluctuant measurements and enhance online detection applications. Finally, simulations and experiments are conducted on the developed cyber-physical testbed to demonstrate the superiority of proposed scheme.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This article proposes a novel, joint False Data Injection Attack (FDIA) detection and localization scheme for power distribution systems, utilizing an **adversarial anomaly transformer**.

The scheme addresses the overgeneralization issue common in reconstruction-based unsupervised methods by:
1.  Introducing an **anomaly attention mechanism** to enhance the distinguishability between normal and attacked data.
2.  Employing a **generative adversarial network (GAN) framework** to accurately model data distribution.
3.  Using a **drift streaming peaks over threshold (POT) dynamic threshold method** to adapt to fluctuating measurements and improve online detection capabilities.

The superiority of the proposed scheme is demonstrated through extensive simulations and experiments conducted on a developed cyber-physical power distribution simulation system testbed.

title: DeMo: Experiences of Deploying a Large-Scale Indoor Delivery Monitoring System
abstract: The delivery of goods to numerous indoor stores poses significant safety risks, with heavy, high-stacked packages on delivery trolleys posing a potential hazard to passersby. This paper reports our experiences of developing and operating DeMo, a practical system for real-time monitoring of indoor delivery. DeMo employs sensors attached to trolleys, utilizing Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) and Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) readings to detect delivery violations, such as speeding and the use of non-designated delivery paths, and ensure accurate matching of each delivery to its intended destination store. Unlike typical indoor localization applications, DeMo addresses unique challenges, including sensor placement and the complex electromagnetic characteristics encountered in underground settings. Specifically, DeMo adapts the classical logarithmic radio signal model to facilitate fingerprint-free localization, significantly reducing deployment and maintenance costs. DeMo has been operating since May 2020, covering more than 200 shops with 74,537 deliveries (6193.2 km) across 12 subway stations in Hong Kong. DeMo’s 4-year operation witnessed a significant violation rate drop, from 19% (May 2020) to 0.9% (Mar 2024).
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper introduces DeMo, a real-time monitoring system designed to mitigate safety risks associated with indoor goods delivery, where heavy, high-stacked packages on trolleys can endanger passersby.

DeMo utilizes IMU and BLE sensors attached to delivery trolleys to detect safety violations, such as speeding and deviations from designated delivery paths, and to ensure accurate delivery to the intended store. A key innovation of DeMo is its ability to perform fingerprint-free localization by adapting the classical logarithmic radio signal model, addressing unique challenges like complex electromagnetic characteristics in underground settings and difficult sensor placement, which significantly reduces deployment and maintenance costs.

Deployed since May 2020 across 12 subway stations in Hong Kong, serving over 200 shops and monitoring more than 74,000 deliveries (6,193.2 km), DeMo has demonstrated remarkable success. Over its four-year operation, it has drastically reduced the delivery violation rate from 19% in May 2020 to a mere 0.9% by March 2024.

ASSM: Adaptive Subject-Focused Modeling for Multimodal Summarization via Semantic Matching
venue: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: Multimodal Summarization aims to use multimodal data to generate accurate and concise summaries for long sentences. While previous work has achieved promising success, they have overlooked the mismatching among multimodal semantics and lacked subject information guidance for adaptive referential images. Motivated by this observation, we propose ASSM, an Adaptive Subject-focused modeling for multimodal summarization via Semantic Matching. The novelty of ASSM lies in two aspects. First, we propose a multimodal semantic matching module that projects multimodal inputs into a shared joint embedding semantic space to determine whether the semantics between multimodalities are mismatching. Second, we propose an adaptive subject-focused guide module, which adaptively references images to learn subject tokens based on the multimodal semantic matching results. With these subject tokens, we are able to focus on the subject information, providing precise guidance for summary generation. We conduct extensive experiments on two standard benchmarks and compare ASSM with 17 existing models. The experimental results regarding ROUGE, BERTScore, and MoverScore show that the proposed ASSM model outperforms all competitors, achieving state-of-the-art performance and suggesting the effectiveness of our proposal. In addition, we provide a case study to further demonstrate the usability of ASSM.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper introduces ASSM (Adaptive Subject-focused modeling for multimodal summarization via Semantic Matching) to address two limitations in previous multimodal summarization methods: overlooked semantic mismatch between modalities and a lack of subject-information guidance for adaptive image referencing.

ASSM proposes two key novelties:
1.  **Multimodal Semantic Matching Module:** This module projects multimodal inputs into a shared embedding space to identify semantic mismatches between modalities.
2.  **Adaptive Subject-focused Guide Module:** Based on the semantic matching results, this module adaptively references images to learn "subject tokens," which then provide precise, subject-focused guidance for summary generation.

Extensive experiments on two standard benchmarks demonstrate that ASSM outperforms 17 existing models, achieving state-of-the-art performance across ROUGE, BERTScore, and MoverScore metrics, confirming its effectiveness. A case study further illustrates its usability.

DTWformer: A DTW-Based Transformer for Multivariate Time Series Forecasting
abstract: Accurate and robust time series forecasting is critical in numerous domains but remains challenging due to issues such as temporal misalignments, noise, and complex multivariate dependencies. Transformer-based models have demonstrated strong performance in sequential tasks; however, their reliance on dot-product attention renders them sensitive to noise and less effective for misaligned time series. To address these limitations, we propose a novel dynamic time warping (DTW)-based attention mechanism, leveraging a Sakoe-Chiba-constrained soft-DTW framework to replace the traditional dot-product similarity. This approach enables dynamic sequence alignment, enhancing robustness to temporal misalignments. Building on this innovation, we introduce DTWformer, a multi-scale Transformer model that integrates DTW-attention with adaptive patching to capture dependencies across varying temporal resolutions. DTWformer achieves superior forecasting performance and efficiency, addressing the limitations of existing approaches in handling misaligned and noisy time series.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper addresses the challenges in time series forecasting, particularly those arising from temporal misalignments, noise, and complex dependencies, which limit the effectiveness of traditional Transformer models due to their dot-product attention's sensitivity.

The authors propose a novel **dynamic time warping (DTW)-based attention mechanism** that replaces the standard dot-product similarity with a Sakoe-Chiba-constrained soft-DTW framework. This innovation enables dynamic sequence alignment, significantly improving robustness to temporal misalignments.

Building on this, they introduce **DTWformer**, a multi-scale Transformer model that integrates this DTW-attention with adaptive patching to capture dependencies across varying temporal resolutions. DTWformer is claimed to achieve superior forecasting performance and efficiency, effectively overcoming the limitations of existing approaches in handling misaligned and noisy time series.

title: Knowledge Aggregation Transformer Network for Multivariate Time Series Classification
abstract: Over the years, various sophisticated deep learning algorithms have surfaced for multivariate time series classification (MTSC), notably the dual-network-based model. This model comprises two parallel networks tailored to time series data: one for local feature extraction and the other for global relation extraction. However, effectively integrating these dual networks poses a significant challenge. To address this, we propose a knowledge aggregation transformer network (KATN) for MTSC. KATN, composed of four aggregation transformer blocks, extracts abundant regularizations and connections hidden within the data. Each block incorporates a modified residual network (MResNet) for local feature extraction and a multi-head attention network for global relation extraction. Initially, the block merges MResNet’s output feature with that of the multi-head attention network through an additive operation. Subsequently, it aligns features with a fully connected (i.e., dense) layer and activates neural units using the Gaussian error linear unit function. This strategic feature aggregation allows for capturing long-range dependencies among multiple variables in multivariate time series data. Experimental results demonstrate that KATN significantly outperforms 6 state-of-the-art transformer variants, achieving a ‘win’/‘tie’/‘lose’ record of 9/6/15 and securing the lowest AVG_rank score. Furthermore, when evaluated against 18 existing MTSC algorithms across 13 UEA datasets, KATN consistently delivers superior performance, attaining the lowest AVG_rank score among all compared methods.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This paper introduces the **Knowledge Aggregation Transformer Network (KATN)** to address the challenge of effectively integrating local and global feature extraction networks in Multivariate Time Series Classification (MTSC).

Traditional dual-network models for MTSC separate local and global feature extraction but struggle with their integration. KATN tackles this by employing four aggregation transformer blocks. Each block leverages a modified Residual Network (MResNet) for local feature extraction and a multi-head attention network for global relation extraction. The key innovation lies in its aggregation strategy: MResNet's output and the multi-head attention network's output are merged through an additive operation, then processed by a fully connected layer with a Gaussian error linear unit (GELU) activation. This method effectively captures long-range dependencies across multiple variables.

Experimental results demonstrate KATN's superior performance:
*   It significantly outperforms 6 state-of-the-art transformer variants with a 9/6/15 win/tie/lose record and the lowest average rank.
*   It consistently achieves the lowest average rank when compared against 18 existing MTSC algorithms across 13 UEA datasets.

title: PPTP: Performance-Guided Physiological Signal-Based Trust Prediction in Sequential Human-Robot Collaboration
abstract: Trust prediction is a key issue in human-robot collaboration, especially in construction scenarios where maintaining appropriate trust calibration is critical for safety and efficiency. This letter introduces the Performance-guided Physiological signal-based Trust Prediction (PPTP), a novel framework designed to improve trust assessment. We designed a sequential human-robot construction scenario with three difficulty levels to induce different trust states, where human and robot alternately perform subtasks toward a shared goal. Our approach integrates synchronized multimodal physiological signals (ECG, GSR, and EMG) with collaboration performance evaluation to predict human trust levels. Individual physiological signals are processed using collaboration performance information as guiding cues, leveraging the standardized nature of collaboration performance to compensate for individual variations in physiological responses. Extensive experiments demonstrate the efficacy of our cross-modality fusion method in significantly improving trust classification performance. Our model achieves over 81% accuracy in three-level trust classification, outperforming the best baseline method by 6.7%, and notably reaches 74.3% accuracy in high-resolution seven-level classification, which is a first in trust prediction research. Ablation experiments further validate the superiority of physiological signal processing guided by collaboration performance assessment.
abstract_summary_gcp:
This letter introduces the **Performance-guided Physiological signal-based Trust Prediction (PPTP)** framework, a novel approach for improving trust assessment in human-robot collaboration, particularly in construction scenarios where appropriate trust calibration is vital for safety and efficiency.

PPTP integrates synchronized multimodal physiological signals (ECG, GSR, EMG) with collaboration performance evaluation. Its key innovation lies in using collaboration performance information as guiding cues to process individual physiological signals. This method leverages the standardized nature of performance to compensate for individual variations in physiological responses, making trust prediction more robust.

The framework was tested in a sequential human-robot construction scenario with three difficulty levels, designed to induce different trust states. Experiments demonstrated that this cross-modality fusion significantly improves trust classification performance. The PPTP model achieved over **81% accuracy** in three-level trust classification, surpassing the best baseline by 6.7%. Notably, it also reached **74.3% accuracy** in a high-resolution seven-level classification, marking a first in trust prediction research. Ablation studies further validated the superiority of the performance-guided physiological signal processing approach.
